instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..

threads.title: Macbook Air  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B USB Power
threads.message:
Hi, i have a Macbook Air 2014 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B logic board with non working USB port, i have 5v on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> on pins 2 and 3 but 0v on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3_RTUSB_A_ILIM</SIGNAL> pins 6 and 7, pin 8 is 3v
so i replaced <CHIP>U4600</CHIP> but i still have no 5v on pins 6 and 7, i then checked <SIGNAL>USB_PWRT_EN</SIGNAL> on pin 4 and i got 0.80v, i then checked <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on <RESISTOR>R8117</RESISTOR> and i got 2.3v, 100 ohms on <RESISTOR>R8117</RESISTOR>, my best guess is i have problem on my USB power enable but no idea whats next.

threads.title: Macbook Air  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B USB Power
threads.message:
Please confirm which USB port doesn't work; just onboard J4600, or both.
You can remove <CHIP>U4600</CHIP> and check if <SIGNAL>USB_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> comes on high.

Any history available, liquid damage?

threads.title: Macbook Air  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B USB Power
threads.message: Macbook Air works fine without any liquid damage, both ports not working, removed the <CHIP>U4600</CHIP> <SIGNAL>USB_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> is 0.80v

threads.title: Macbook Air  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B USB Power
threads.message: Change <RESISTOR>R8117</RESISTOR> and check continuity with <CHIP>U4600</CHIP> enable pin.

threads.title: Macbook Air  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B USB Power
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R8117</RESISTOR> measures correct in and out of circuit but replaced it anyway with new one and now USB ports works, thanks

threads.title: Macbook Air  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B USB Power
threads.message: Back with the same problem, after few hours of usage USB ports don't work anymore, <RESISTOR>R8117</RESISTOR> <SIGNAL>USB_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> is 0.80v , <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on <RESISTOR>R8117</RESISTOR> and i got 2.3v

threads.title: Macbook Air  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B USB Power
threads.message: i removed <CHIP>U4600</CHIP> again and measured <SIGNAL>USB_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> still 0.80v, whats supposed to be the voltage of <SIGNAL>USB_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: Macbook Air  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B USB Power
threads.message: <SIGNAL>USB_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> to ground is 58 ohm? is that a short?

threads.title: Macbook Air  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B USB Power
Macbook Air  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B USB Power
threads.message:
If you get 58 ohms after U400 removed, you have a inside board leakage.
In this case, solder <RESISTOR>R8117</RESISTOR> on pin 1 only and run tiny wire from its pin 2 directly to pin 4 of <CHIP>U4600</CHIP>.
But you MUST cut off the trace from pin 4 to the rest of board.

I suppose R/<CAPACITOR>C8114</CAPACITOR> are not soldered and no corrosion present on their pads.

threads.title: Macbook Air  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B USB Power
threads.message:
Just to make sure before i do that, <CHIP>U4600</CHIP> removed then <RESISTOR>R8117</RESISTOR> pin 1 = 2.3v and pin 2 = 0.80v, i then removed <RESISTOR>R8117</RESISTOR> and i then checked <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on <RESISTOR>R8117</RESISTOR> pin 1 pad is measured 3.3v, does it confirm there's a leakage on <RESISTOR>R8117</RESISTOR> pin 2 pad to <CHIP>U4600</CHIP> pin 4?


with <RESISTOR>R8117</RESISTOR> abd <CHIP>U4600</CHIP> removed here are the resistance to GND

<RESISTOR>R8117</RESISTOR> pin 2 pad = 121 Ohms
<RESISTOR>R8117</RESISTOR> pin 1 pad = 94 Ohms

threads.title: Macbook Air  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B USB Power
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 54070"]If you get 58 ohms after U400 removed, you have a inside board leakage.
In this case, solder <RESISTOR>R8117</RESISTOR> on pin 1 only and run tiny wire from its pin 2 directly to pin 4 of <CHIP>U4600</CHIP>.
But you MUST cut off the trace from pin 4 to the rest of board.

I suppose R/<CAPACITOR>C8114</CAPACITOR> are not soldered and no corrosion present on their pads.[/QUOTE]


Cut the trace before the pin 4? will that disable also <SIGNAL>USB_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> on J9500 pin 3?

threads.title: Macbook Air  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B USB Power
threads.message:
Oops, I forgot too search for all occurrencies of that signal.
In this case, check diode mode to ground disconnecting LIO flex.
Your problem could be in LIO board.
If still low, inspect J9500 for corrosion.
